titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Finding aid prepared by Brian Carpenter

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-09-13T21:11-0400

did.unittitle: Interviews concerning the paintings of the Seneca artist Ernest Smith
did.abstract: Interviews and discussions with the Seneca artist Ernest Smith on his paintings of Seneca customs, stories, ceremonies, crafts, food preparation, and other traditional ways. Smith was a Seneca from the Tonawanda Reservation in New York state. The paintings were done in the 1930s and are presently in the Rochester Museum and Science Center in Rochester, New York. The recordings were made by William N. Fenton and his student, Jeanette Collamer, in 1973 at the museum in Rochester. The paintings are referred to on the recordings by the museum's catalog numbers for the paintings. Some of the paintings do not have assigned titles. Sound quality is fair overall, with severe distortion and prominent background noise on the final tape.
did.physdesc: 11 sound tape reels (29 hr., 41 min.) : analog, 1 7/8 ips, 1/2 track, mono ; 5 in.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by William N. Fenton in 1985.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Contents of tapes 1 and 2 (original tape numbers 1 and 1A) are identical. Tape 2 not transferred to DAT.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Interview with Seneca artist Ernest Smith regarding his paintings held at the Rochester Museum. The paintings are referred to by their Museum catalog numbers.

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals note
originalsloc.p: This file is a compressed, digitized version of the original. The APS Library maintains the original format (Sound tape reel) as well as an uncompressed digitized version of this recording.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Discussions with Ernest Smith regarding Flute Player, Courting Flute, Fish Dance Song, Burnin [sic] Springs, Stories to Scare Children (Long Nose, Legs, Flapping Ears). A very distorted program, with prominent uncorrected background noise.
